generif.text: MN1 is a 1,25-(OH)2D3-induced vitamin D receptor coactivator that also may have critical roles in modulating osteoblast proliferation.
MN1-translocation-ETS-leukemia exerts its nonlineage-specific leukemogenic effects by promoting the growth of primitive progenitors and blocking their differentiation
leukemogenic effect of MN1-ets variant gene 6 L in our knock-in mice is pleiotropic, and the type of secondary mutation determines disease outcome
Up-regulates Insulin-Like Growth Factor Binding Protein 5 at a specific promoter consensus sequence.
MN1 is a unique oncogene in hematopoiesis that both promotes proliferation/self-renewal and blocks differentiation, and may become useful as a predictive marker in AML treatment.
MN1 overexpression is associated with the development of inv(16) acute myeloid leukemia
role of MN1 in myeloid leukemia [review]
MN1 and MN1-TEL interfere with the ATRA pathway and this might explain the differentiation block in leukemias in which these genes are involved.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
Data demonstrate that MN1 overexpression correlates with progression from MDS to sAML and therefore might be involved in the pathogenesis of sAML
MN1 expression independently predicts outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia
Down-regulation of CEBPA activity contributes to MN1-modulated proliferation and impaired myeloid differentiation of hematopoietic cells.
high MN1 levels are important for the growth of leukemic cells, and that increased MN1 expression can synergize with MLL-ENL and probably other transforming fusion genes in leukemia induction.
MN1-ETV6 fusion gene arising from Myelodysplastic Syndrome with 5q trisomy is associated with acute myeloid leukemia.

low MN1 expression confers better prognosis in older CN-AML patients and may refine the European LeukemiaNet classification. Biologic features associated with MN1 expression may help identify new treatment targets.
analysis of genetic variants hints at the contribution of TGFB3 and MN1 in the aetiology of submucous cleft palate
A high MEBE (MN1,ERG, BAALC, EVI1) expression score is an unfavorable prognostic marker in Myelodysplastic syndrome and is associated with an increased risk for progression to Acute myeloid leukemia.
Overexpression of MN1 confers resistance to chemotherapy, accelerates leukemia onset, and suppresses p53 and Bim induction
MN1 overexpression independently predicts bad clinical outcome in CN-AML patients
High MN1 expression confers worse prognosis in Chinese adult patients with de novo acute myeloid leukemia.
cotransduction of an activated HOX gene (NUP98HOXD13) with MN1 induces a serially transplantable acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
identified potential driver mutations in NF2 (neurofibromatosis type 2) and MN1 (meningioma 1).

genotype-phenotype correlation among our patients and those previously reported with overlapping 22q12 deletions, we identified a 560 kb critical region containing the MN1 gene that is implicated in human cleft palate formation
Chromosome 22q12.1 microdeletions involving the MN1 gene confirm it as a candidate gene for cleft palate.
these results suggest that deregulated MN1 expression contributes to the pathogenesis of pediatric B-ALL.
MN1 deletion is associated with Craniofacial Abnormalities.
MLL1 and DOT1L cooperate with meningioma-1 to induce acute myeloid leukemia.

The data obtained show that normal cells consistently express low levels of MN1 transcript. In contrast, high levels of MN1 expression are present in 47% of patients with normal karyotype and in all cases with inv(16).
MN1 gene expression in acute myeloid leukemia.
Study suggests a role for DNMT3B in leukemogenesis in inv(16) acute myeloid leukemia, through MN1 methylation regulation.
Patients with t(12;22)/MN1-EVT6 oncogene, are frequently associated with myeloid neoplasms, poor response to chemotherapy, and inferior outcome.
MN1-rearranged astroblastoma brain tumors were characterized by better overall survival compared to other genetic subtypes.

results indicate that (1) high levels of MN1 expression contribute to poor colorectal cancer (CRC) prognosis and (2) MN1 can serve as a novel potential biomarker in predicting the prognosis of CRC patients.
Meningioma 1 is indispensable for mixed lineage leukemia-rearranged acute myeloid leukemia.
MN1 C-terminal truncation syndrome is a novel neurodevelopmental and craniofacial disorder with partial rhombencephalosynapsis.
Gain-of-Function MN1 Truncation Variants Cause Craniofacial and Brain Abnormalities.
Spinal cord astroblastoma with an EWSR1-BEND2 fusion classified as a high-grade neuroepithelial tumour with MN1 alteration.
MN1 Linked to Syndrome Characterized by Craniofacial Abnormalities and Severe Developmental Delay.
Allogeneic stem cell transplantation mitigates the adverse prognostic impact of high diagnostic BAALC and MN1 expression in AML.
MN1 overexpression with varying tumor grade is a promising predictor of survival of glioma patients.
Frequent MN1 Gene Mutations in Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor.
Prognostic significance of combined BAALC and MN1 gene expression level in acute myeloid leukemia with normal karyotype.
Unique pathological findings of astroblastoma with MN1 alteration in a patient with late recurrence.
Intrinsically disordered Meningioma-1 stabilizes the BAF complex to cause AML.
Novel truncating variant of MN1 penultimate exon identified in a Chinese patient with newly recognized MN1 C-terminal truncation syndrome: Case report and literature review.
METTL14-mediated epitranscriptome modification of MN1 mRNA promote tumorigenicity and all-trans-retinoic acid resistance in osteosarcoma.
Early ependymal tumor with MN1-BEND2 fusion: a mostly cerebral tumor of female children with a good prognosis that is distinct from classical astroblastoma.
Distinctive Craniofacial and Oral Anomalies in MN1 C-terminal Truncation Syndrome.
Variants in HCFC1 and MN1 genes causing intellectual disability in two Pakistani families.

BP.term: positive regulation of vitamin D receptor signaling pathway
regulation of cell cycle G1/S phase transition

name: MN1 proto-oncogene, transcriptional regulator
summary: Meningioma 1 (MN1) contains two sets of CAG repeats. It is disrupted by a balanced translocation (4;22) in a meningioma, and its inactivation may contribute to meningioma 32 pathogenesis. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
